name: International Institute of Islamic Thought
theoryOfChange: The International Institute of Islamic Thought (IIIT), through its Advancing Education in Muslim Societies (AEMS) project, has a published conceptual framework and study methods and design. This framework is for their study on “Mapping the Terrain” of education in Muslim Societies. It aims to build upon IIIT's intellectual work in education and address knowledge gaps in values-based education as part of a human development approach, with the long-term goal of contributing to human civilizations.
zakatClaimEvidence: The official Wikipedia page for the International Institute of Islamic Thought (IIIT), a US-based non-profit organization in Herndon, Virginia, outlines its objectives as reviving and reforming Islamic thought through research, advancing education in Muslim societies, and publishing, translating, and teaching this work. There is no mention of accepting zakat donations, dedicated zakat funds, or serving zakat-eligible recipients on this page or in other search results specifically pertaining to the US organization.

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years

all_citations.claim: The organization publishes scholarly work on Usul al-Fiqh and Islamic methodology.
IIIT is recognized for its contributions to Islamic legal methodology.
The institute produces numerous scholarly titles as part of its core mission.
The organization provides resources on the Islamic vision of development.

The organization reported total revenue of $8,955,918 and a program expense ratio of 95.0%.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization receives a moderate score reflecting its strong financial allocation toward programs, balanced against a lack of independent impact verification and low donor alignment for general Muslim giving.
areas_for_improvement: Limited transparency regarding specific program outcomes and measurable impact data
Low data confidence due to reliance on self-reported scholarly materials and limited third-party evaluations

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization serves a niche religious and cultural cause focused on academic reform, which may result in low alignment for donors seeking direct humanitarian aid [6]. Its track record is established through decades of scholarly contributions, though it lacks broad-based donor fit metrics [2][5].
dimension_explanations.impact: IIIT demonstrates a focus on capacity building through its Winter Student Program (WSP) and the publication of academic texts on Usul al-Fiqh [1][3]. While the organization maintains a high program expense ratio of 95.0%, there is limited external data to verify the long-term effectiveness of its leadership training [7][8].

baseline_narrative.headline: The International Institute of Islamic Thought (IIIT) is a scholarly organization dedicated to the advancement of Islamic legal methodology and intellectual leadership through academic training and publications.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 95.0% indicating a strong commitment to direct mission-related activities
Robust scholarly output with numerous publications on Islamic legal methodology and civilization
Established educational infrastructure including the Muslim Leadership Training Program and Winter Student Program
baseline_narrative.summary: The International Institute of Islamic Thought (IIIT) focuses on the reform of Islamic thought and the integration of knowledge through specialized educational programs and scholarly research [1][3]. The organization reported a total revenue of $8,955,918 and operates with a high program expense ratio of 95.0% [7][8].

impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence in this sector helps donors understand how academic research translates into practical community leadership and social change.

strengths.detail: The organization maintains a <cite id="8">program expense ratio of 95.0%</cite>, which significantly exceeds the <cite id="7">peer program ratio median of 81.7%</cite>.
IIIT has published <cite id="3">600 scholarly titles</cite> focusing on Islamic legal methodology and <cite id="1">Usul al-Fiqh</cite>.
The organization operates with a <cite id="7">100% independent board of directors</cite>, ensuring objective oversight.

strengths_deep_dive: IIIT's primary strength lies in its deep intellectual infrastructure. By focusing on <cite id="1">Islamic studies pedagogy</cite> and the <cite id="3">reform of Islamic thought</cite>, it fills a unique gap in the religious-cultural sector. Its financial model is highly lean, with <cite id="7">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, meaning nearly every dollar of its <cite id="8">$8.9 million in contributions</cite> is utilized for academic and capacity-building programs rather than administrative overhead.
rich_narrative.summary: The International Institute of Islamic Thought (IIIT) is a specialized academic institution dedicated to the <cite id="1">advancement of Islamic legal methodology</cite> and the <cite id="3">integration of knowledge within Islamic civilization</cite>. Operating primarily as a scholarly hub, IIIT focuses on intellectual leadership through the production of <cite id="3">over 600 scholarly titles</cite> and the management of high-level educational initiatives. The organization reported <cite id="8">total revenue of $8,955,918</cite> in 2023, with a significant <cite id="8">program expense ratio of 95.0%</cite>, indicating that the vast majority of its financial resources are directed toward its academic mission. Key programs include the <cite id="1">Muslim Leadership Training Program</cite> and the <cite id="1">Winter Student Program in Islamic Studies</cite>, which aim to equip students and researchers with a <cite id="3">new perspective on Usul al-Fiqh</cite>. While the organization maintains a <cite id="7">100% independent board</cite>, its focus remains niche, serving the global academic community and those interested in the <cite id="1">reform of Islamic thought</cite>.
